en: Interview with Eric Dobell, an entertainer and resident of Gatlinburg. Dobell recounts his short time in Gatlinburg before the wildfire before discussing the day of the fire itself. He talks about his evacuation efforts in a town where he had few personal ties in the community and about changes he has seen in the city following the disaster. This is a representative quote from the interview: "And for the first year or two, even when there'd be fog, because sometimes the fog--and you get a lot of fog around here--the fog with the lights, would look similar to what it looked like that day and that would freak me out."
Individuals (tourists or locals) directly affected by the fire

Interview with Eric Dobell, an entertainer and resident of Gatlinburg. Dobell recounts his short time in Gatlinburg before the wildfire before discussing the day of the fire itself. He talks about his evacuation efforts in a town where he had few personal ties in the community and about changes he has seen in the city following the disaster. This is a representative quote from the interview: "And for the first year or two, even when there'd be fog, because sometimes the fog--and you get a lot of fog around here--the fog with the lights, would look similar to what it looked like that day and that would freak me out."

Why did you decide to particpate in this project?
Can you tell us a little about yourself and your life in Gatlinburg?
What's it like living in a city with a lot of tourists where you provide entertainment?
Are you involved in the community in any ways?
You mentioned moving here in 2016, what ws it like moving here during that time?
What do you remember about the day of the fire and the days leading up to it?
What part of town do you live in?
Did you see any houses on fire?
So you saw fire as you were driving to evacuate?
You mentioned your spouse earlier, was she in the U.S. at the time?
That night and following days, how were you keeping in touch with people?
What ws it like the first time coing back into Gatlinburg?
Do you feel like other people you've spoken with share difficulties like nightmares?
Were you concerned that people wouldn't come back to Gatlinburg?
When people did start coming back, what were some of your interactions with visitors? Did you modify your act any in response to the fire?
Do you feel that people know that there was a fire three years ago?
How would you assess how Gatlinburg is recovering?
How do you feel that the fire has shaped community relations?
Are you still living in the Ski Mountain area? How does it feel being up there with all the reminders?
Do you feel like you've made any provisions for another disaster?
Was there anything else surprising or good that came out of this?
Is there anything that we haven't covered that you would like to share?

seo.title: Interview with Erik Dobell, 2020-02-22 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
